feed.title: Apache Gluten incubating
feed.subtitle: Gluten is a middle layer responsible for offloading JVM-based SQL engines' execution to native engines.

entry.title: Glutencon2025 English
entry.content:
ğŸ‰ GlutenCon 2025 â€” First Annual Conference Officially Launched!

Welcome to the annual gathering of the Gluten community â€” GlutenCon 2025!

ğŸ“… Date: Saturday, December 6, 2025
ğŸ•˜ Time: 09:00 AM â€“ 06:00 PM
ğŸ“ Location: ByteDance Headquarters, Beijing (Building 1, Dazhongsi Plaza, No.18 Jia, North Third Ring West Road, Haidian District)
ğŸ¯ Hosted by: Apache Gluten Community & ByteDance

ğŸ§­ About the Event

Gluten is an open-source project focused on accelerating data processing. It enhances the performance of engines like Spark through native vectorized execution, decoupled backend architecture, and modern hardware optimization.

This conference will bring together technical experts from the community, industry, and academia to explore topics such as Apache Gluten project updates, execution optimization practices, multi-backend integration, and open-source governance.

ğŸŒŸ Event Highlights

  • Apache Gluten Project Updates
  • Major Announcements from ByteDance
  • Technical Talks + Community Networking + Real-World Use Cases
  • Free Tickets with Lunch, Coffee, and Swag Included

ğŸ“ Registration

ğŸŸ Free Admission: Includes lunch, refreshments, and conference swag
ğŸ“£ CFP Deadline: Open now until December 1, 2025
ğŸ”— [Scan QR Code to Register]

ğŸ—£ Speakers

  • To be announced!

ğŸ“š Agenda

  • Coming soon!

ğŸ™Œ Join Us

Whether youâ€™re a developer, architect, data platform engineer, or open-source enthusiast, GlutenCon welcomes your participation!

Letâ€™s build an open, professional, and warm technical gathering together!

ğŸ“Œ Follow Gluten GitHub for updates
ğŸ“§ Questions? Contact us at: dev@gluten.apache.org
entry.summary: ğŸ‰ GlutenCon 2025 â€” First Annual Conference Officially Launched!

entry.title: Gluten 1.2.0 Release
entry.content:
On Sept. 3rd 2024, I am thrilled to share that Apache Gluten (incubating) has celebrated its 1st Apache official release, version 1.2.0, featuring the following highlights.

Whatâ€™s new in Gluten 1.2.0

  • Support Spark 3.2.2, 3.3.1, 3.4.2, and 3.5.1 with all UTs passed(if data type supported)
  • Support 31 common Spark Operators(based on Spark3.2)
  • Support 266 common Spark Functions(based on Spark3.2)
  • Velox codebase updated to 2024/07/05
  • New RSS support: add Apache Uniffle integration
  • New Data Lake support: Iceberge, Delta Lake
  • New File Format Support: CSV
  • Enhanced CI workflow
  • Refresh Documentations in Gluten website(https://gluten.apache.org/)
  • More Stability in Spill, OOM, and other cases support
  • More Bug Fixing

For further information, please check

Downloads

Release Notes

Documentations

About How to Contribute to Gluten

Contact Us
entry.summary: On Sept. 3rd 2024, I am thrilled to share that Apache Gluten (incubating) has celebrated its 1st Apache official release, version 1.2.0, featuring the following highlights.

entry.title: Welcome to Jekyll!
entry.content:
Youâ€™ll find this post in your _posts directory. Go ahead and edit it and re-build the site to see your changes. You can rebuild the site in many different ways, but the most common way is to run jekyll serve, which launches a web server and auto-regenerates your site when a file is updated.

Jekyll requires blog post files to be named according to the following format:

YEAR-MONTH-DAY-title.MARKUP

Where YEAR is a four-digit number, MONTH and DAY are both two-digit numbers, and MARKUP is the file extension representing the format used in the file. After that, include the necessary front matter. Take a look at the source for this post to get an idea about how it works.

Jekyll also offers powerful support for code snippets:

Check out the Jekyll docs for more info on how to get the most out of Jekyll. File all bugs/feature requests at Jekyllâ€™s GitHub repo. If you have questions, you can ask them on Jekyll Talk.
entry.summary: Youâ€™ll find this post in your _posts directory. Go ahead and edit it and re-build the site to see your changes. You can rebuild the site in many different ways, but the most common way is to run jekyll serve, which launches a web server and auto-regenerates your site when a file is updated.
